messages.content:
i used @sys/backup.bat file to upload all files into my github, but got this error:
warning: in the working copy of 'blueprint-gui/package-lock.json', LF will be replaced by CRLF the next time Git touches it
warning: in the working copy of 'blueprint-gui/package.json', LF will be replaced by CRLF the next time Git touches it
warning: in the working copy of 'blueprint-gui/public/index.html', LF will be replaced by CRLF the next time Git touches it
[main c3d5460] Automated backup 2025-09-19 17:05:36.37
 4 files changed, 4443 insertions(+), 19379 deletions(-)
ssh: Could not resolve hostname ssh.github.com: Name or service not known
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.
--- Content from referenced files ---
Content from @C:\Users\USER\Documents\code\sys\backup.bat:
@echo off
cd "C:\Users\USER\Documents\code"
git add .
git commit -m "Automated backup %date% %time%"
git push origin main
pause
--- End of content ---

It looks like the push to GitHub failed because of an incorrect server address. The error `Could not resolve hostname ssh.github.com` indicates that your git configuration is trying to connect to `ssh.github.com`, but the correct address is `github.com`.

I'll check your git remote configuration to confirm this.

thoughts.subject: Analyzing Backup Failure
thoughts.description: I've been examining the user's issue with the backup script. Specifically, I'm focusing on the `backup.bat` script and how it interacts with GitHub. The user reported an error related to backing up files. I'm trying to figure out what might have gone wrong with the `backup.bat` script and how to diagnose the issue. I suspect the issue is related to the scripts structure.

thoughts.subject: Verifying Git Configuration
thoughts.description: I'm now zeroing in on the Git configuration. The error message clearly indicates a hostname resolution problem, pointing to an incorrect remote URL. I need to verify the `origin` remote's configuration. I'll execute `git remote -v` to check the fetch and push URLs. My suspicion is the URL will be formatted incorrectly, with `ssh.github.com` instead of `github.com`. Correcting this misconfiguration seems like the next logical step to resolve the backup issue.

thoughts.subject: Reviewing Git Remotes
thoughts.description: My immediate focus is on the Git remote configuration. The error clearly points to a hostname resolution failure with `ssh.github.com`. I've analyzed the user's provided `backup.bat` script and pinpointed the likely culprit: an incorrect remote URL. To verify my hypothesis, I'll execute `git remote -v` to check the current `origin` remote's configuration. I'm almost certain the fetch and push URLs will be incorrectly formatted, possibly using `ssh.github.com` instead of the required `github.com`.  Correcting this is the immediate next step. I'll need to extract the user and repository name to form the corrected URL.
